keyTakeAways: The AWS outage was caused by a technical error during an update to DynamoDB's API, which disrupted the Domain Name System (DNS) and prevented apps from connecting to critical cloud services.
The outage affected 113 AWS services, including major platforms such as Snapchat, Pinterest, WhatsApp, Roblox, Fortnite, Apple TV, Starbucks, Duolingo, Canva, and financial apps like Venmo.
The root cause was human error, not a cyberattack, as confirmed by cybersecurity expert Bryson Bort of Scythe.
AWS acknowledged the issue, deployed multiple recovery paths, and reported full resolution by 10:11 GMT, though some users experienced message processing backlogs.

Cloud outages are increasingly significant due to the widespread reliance on cloud infrastructure, with AWS holding a 30% market share and powering essential services across banking, gaming, media, and smart home devices.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major AWS outage on Monday, beginning at 07:11 GMT, was caused by a technical error during an update to DynamoDB’s API, which disrupted the Domain Name System (DNS) and prevented apps from connecting to essential cloud services. This cascading failure affected 113 AWS services, including Snapchat, Pinterest, WhatsApp, Roblox, Fortnite, Apple TV, Starbucks, Duolingo, Canva, financial apps like Venmo, and major media outlets such as The New York Times and the Associated Press. Although AWS resolved the issue by 10:11 GMT, users faced delays and message backlogs. Experts, including Joshua Mahony and Bryson Bort, noted that the outage resulted from human error, not a cyberattack, and emphasized that such incidents are common in cloud-dependent ecosystems. The event underscores the critical role of cloud infrastructure in modern digital life, with AWS holding a dominant 30% market share and powering essential services across banking, gaming, media, and smart homes.
title: What caused Amazon’s AWS outage, and why did so many major apps go offline?
